subSubSection.paragraph:
The following character combination distinguishes
T. rufescens
from
T. glabratum
and
T. signatum
: dorsum of mesosoma with dense reticulate punctate sculpture and propodeal spines long and narrow (PSLI 16–23).

materialsCitation.paragraph: NAMIBIA : 3 pinned workers, Swakopmund, 12–19Apr. 1911 , W. Michaelsen leg. ( ZMHB : FOCOL2082 to FOCOL2084).

subSubSection.paragraph: NAMIBIA (148 pinned specimens): Spitzkoppe, 21°50′ S , 15°11′ E , 6–7 Mar. 1995 , pitfall traps, E.S. Ross and A.R. Stephen leg. ( CASC : CASENT-0217976 (compared with type )); 61.2 km S of Gobabis on C20, at intersection of C20 and D1790, 22°56.806′ S , 18°44.681′ E , 1353 m a.s.l., nesting in red sandy soil, 17 Apr. 2011 , N. caption.paragraph:
Fig. 20.
Tetramorium rufescens Stitz, 1923
(CASENT0250852). A . Body in profile. B . Body in dorsal view. C . Head in full-face view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Tetramorium rufescens
is known from South Africa and Namibia .

The description of this species matches that of Bolton (1980) , except for colour. We observed some variation in the specimens examined, ranging from red to light brown, in those collected at certain localities in South Africa (Klein Pella) and Namibia (Kamanjab, Luderitz District, Daberas, Hobatere, Epupa Falls). This species has been recorded from the Drakensberg Montane Grasslands, Kalahari Xeric Savanna, Nama Karoo, Namib Desert, Namibian Savanna Woodlands and Succulent Karoo.
